'Pleiotropy' occurs when one gene influences multiple phenotypic traits. Stearns, F. W. (2010). One Hundred Years of Pleitropy: A
Retrospective. Genetics 186(3):767-773.
http://www.genetics.org/content/186/3/767.abstract Consequently, a
mutation in a pleiotropic gene may have an effect on some or all traits
simultaneously. This can become a problem when selection on one trait favours
one specific version of the gene (allele), while the selection on the other
trait favors another allele. The underlying mechanism of pleiotropy in most
cases is the effect of a gene on metabolic pathways which contribute toward
different phenotypes.
